question: A 49 years old male with 35 pack years presented with painless mass in left scrotal sac and microscopic hematuria. On laboratory investigation, Alphafetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
prompt:
A 49 years old male with 35 pack years presented with painless mass in left scrotal sac and microscopic hematuria. On laboratory investigation, Alphafetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?A)Epididymitis
B)Seminoma
C)Renal cell carcinoma
D)Carcinoma lung
output0: The most probable diagnosis is epididymitis, as the patient's symptoms of painless scrotal mass and microscopic hematuria are consistent with this condition. Additionally, the fact that the alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase levels are negative suggests that the patient does not have a germ cell tumor, which is a common cause of scrotal masses in this age group.
output1: The most probable diagnosis is seminoma, which is a type of testicular cancer that typically affects older men. The patient's age, the presence of a painless mass in the left scrotal sac, and the absence of alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase in the blood all support this diagnosis.
output2: The most probable diagnosis for a 49-year-old male with a painless scrotal mass and microscopic hematuria, who has a negative alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase, is renal cell carcinoma. This is because these findings are consistent with a renal cell carcinoma, which is a common malignancy in this age group and can present with these symptoms.
output3: The patient's history of smoking and the presence of painless scrotal mass and microscopic hematuria suggest a diagnosis of lung cancer. The fact that alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase are negative suggests that the tumor is not a germ cell tumor, which is consistent with the diagnosis of lung cancer.

question: An investigator is studying cellular regeneration of epithelial cells. She has obtained a tissue sample from a normal thyroid gland for histopathologic examination. It shows follicles lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei. Which of the following parts of the female reproductive tract is also lined by this type of epithelium?
prompt:
An investigator is studying cellular regeneration of epithelial cells. She has obtained a tissue sample from a normal thyroid gland for histopathologic examination. It shows follicles lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei. Which of the following parts of the female reproductive tract is also lined by this type of epithelium?A)Ovaries
B)Vagina
C)Fallopian tubes
D)Vulva
output0: The epithelium lining the ovaries is also composed of cube-like cells with large central nuclei, similar to the epithelium of the thyroid gland. This type of epithelium is called cuboidal epithelium.
output1: The epithelium lining the follicles of the thyroid gland is similar to the epithelium lining the vagina. Both are lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei. This type of epithelium is called cuboidal epithelium.
output2: The epithelium lining the fallopian tubes is also composed of cuboidal cells with large central nuclei, similar to the cells seen in the thyroid gland. This shared characteristic is the result of a common embryonic origin of these tissues.
output3: The epithelium lining the follicles of the thyroid gland is similar to the epithelium lining the vestibule and the introitus of the vulva. Both are lined by a single layer of cube-like cells with large central nuclei.

question: In a case-control study, what is the impact of a "non-differential" exposure classification error (that is, it occurs with the same probability in the case group and the control group)? the measure of association ?:
correct_answer: It would bring the association measure to the null value.
options: A)It would bring the association measure to the null value.
B)I would skew the result towards the alternative hypothesis.
C)I would skew the result in an unpredictable direction.
D)It would not modify the association measure.
prompt:
In a case-control study, what is the impact of a "non-differential" exposure classification error (that is, it occurs with the same probability in the case group and the control group)? the measure of association ?:A)It would bring the association measure to the null value.
B)I would skew the result towards the alternative hypothesis.
C)I would skew the result in an unpredictable direction.
D)It would not modify the association measure.
output0: If the exposure classification error is non-differential, it means that the error occurs with the same probability in both the case and control groups. This would result in a cancellation of the error, and the association measure would be unaffected.
output1: If there is a non-differential exposure classification error, the measure of association (such as the odds ratio or relative risk) would be skewed towards the alternative hypothesis. This is because the exposure classification error is not differential between the case and control groups, so the association measure would be biased towards a higher estimate of the effect.
output2: When a classification error occurs with the same probability in both the case and control groups, it is considered a "non-differential" error. This means that the error does not systematically bias the association measure in one direction or the other.
output3: A non-differential exposure classification error occurs when the exposure of interest is misclassified with the same probability in both the case and control groups. This type of error does not affect the association measure, as the exposure classification error is not related to the outcome.

question: Arterial supply to floor of mouth & suprahyoid muscle is
prompt:
Arterial supply to floor of mouth & suprahyoid muscle isA)Lingual artery
B)Maxillary artery
C)Inferior alveolar artery
D)Facial artery
output0: The lingual artery is the artery that supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the suprahyoid muscle.
output1: The maxillary artery is the artery that supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the suprahyoid muscle.
output2: The inferior alveolar artery is the artery that supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the suprahyoid muscle. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.
output3: The facial artery supplies blood to the floor of the mouth and the suprahyoid muscle. Therefore, it is the correct answer.

question: Which surface of tooth has most of plaque?
options: B)Incisal one third of tooth surface
prompt:
Which surface of tooth has most of plaque?A)Gingival third of tooth surface
B)Incisal one third of tooth surface
C)Middle third of tooth surface
D)Uniform on all surfaces
output0: The gingival third of the tooth surface is the area where the tooth and the gum meet, and it is here that plaque tends to accumulate most. This is because the gum line provides a sheltered area where plaque can grow and multiply more easily.
output1: The incisal one third of the tooth surface is the most prone to plaque accumulation because it is the most accessible area for bacteria to adhere to. Additionally, this area is often difficult to clean, especially for children, which can contribute to the accumulation of plaque.
output2: The middle third of the tooth surface, also known as the "tooth-to-tooth" surface, tends to have the most plaque due to the fact that it is the most exposed to bacteria and food debris.
output3: The plaque is a biofilm that is formed on all surfaces of the teeth, including the gingival, incisal, and middle thirds. Therefore, the correct answer is that plaque is uniform on all surfaces of the teeth.

question: Which of the following clinical situations patients developed metabolic acidosis (Metabolic acidosis) merger, the highest possible chance of Inborn errors of metabolism of?
correct_answer: 3 weeks large newborns, has been vomiting, not eating, poor vitality. Lactic acid blood Anion gap and increased; Urine Ketones 4+
options: A)3 weeks large newborns, has been vomiting, not eating, poor vitality. Lactic acid blood Anion gap and increased; Urine Ketones 4+
B)10-month-old baby boy persistent diarrhea for three days. Chlorine and high blood appear normal Anion gap
C)3-year-old boy five days of high fever and poor appetite. Increased blood leukocytes
D)8 year-old girl to eat, drink, polyuria but weight loss. Blood glucose 410 mg / dL, blood showing Anion gap increases
prompt:
Which of the following clinical situations patients developed metabolic acidosis (Metabolic acidosis) merger, the highest possible chance of Inborn errors of metabolism of?A)3 weeks large newborns, has been vomiting, not eating, poor vitality. Lactic acid blood Anion gap and increased; Urine Ketones 4+
B)10-month-old baby boy persistent diarrhea for three days. Chlorine and high blood appear normal Anion gap
C)3-year-old boy five days of high fever and poor appetite. Increased blood leukocytes
D)8 year-old girl to eat, drink, polyuria but weight loss. Blood glucose 410 mg / dL, blood showing Anion gap increases
output0: The correct answer is A)3 weeks large newborns, has been vomiting, not eating, poor vitality. Lactic acid blood Anion gap and increased; Urine Ketones 4+ because this clinical situation is most likely to be due to an Inborn error of metabolism, specifically a metabolic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce energy. The increased lactic acid in the blood and the presence of ketones in the urine are both indicative of this.
output1: The patient described in option B is most likely to have developed metabolic acidosis due to a high risk of Inborn errors of metabolism in this age group. Persistent diarrhea and high blood chloride levels are both signs of metabolic acidosis.
output2: The patient described in option C has a higher chance of developing metabolic acidosis due to the presence of high fever and poor appetite, which can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Additionally, the increased blood leukocytes may indicate an infection, which can cause metabolic acidosis.
output3: The patient described in option D is most likely to have Inborn errors of metabolism, specifically a type of metabolic acidosis called diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). This is because DKA is characterized by high blood glucose levels (410 mg / dL), increased blood leukocytes, and a high Anion gap. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of polyuria and weight loss are consistent with DKA.

question: Which is the widow's aery in myocardial infarction?
prompt:
Which is the widow's aery in myocardial infarction?A)Left anterior descending aery
B)Right coronary aery
C)Posterior interventricular aery
D)Left circumflex aery
output0: The Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery is the most common coronary artery to be affected in myocardial infarction. It is responsible for the blood supply to the anterior wall of the heart, which includes the left ventricle. The LAD artery is also known as the "widow-maker" because it is often the cause of sudden death in myocardial infarction.
output1: The right coronary artery is the most commonly affected artery in myocardial infarction, and is often referred to as the "widowmaker" due to the high mortality rate associated with a myocardial infarction in this artery.
output2: The posterior interventricular artery is the widow's aery in myocardial infarction because it is the most commonly affected artery in the posterior wall of the heart, and it is often the last artery to be affected in a myocardial infarction.
output3: The left circumflex artery is the widow's aery in myocardial infarction because it is the last branch of the left coronary artery to be perfused, and it is often the last to be affected in a myocardial infarction.

question: A 65-year-old man, known to have chronic obstructive lung disease for the last 3 years, presents to the emergency department with a cough, breathing difficulty, and increased expectoration for a day. There is no history of fever. His regular medications include inhaled salmeterol and inhaled fluticasone propionate. He was a chronic smoker but quit smoking 2 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), the pulse rate is 88/min, the blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg, and the respirations are 30/min. On physical examination, the use of the accessory muscles of respiration is evident and the arterial saturation of oxygen is 87%. Auscultation of the chest reveals the presence of bilateral rhonchi with diminished breath sounds in both lungs. Which of the following medications, if administered for the next 2 weeks, is most likely to reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months?
prompt:
A 65-year-old man, known to have chronic obstructive lung disease for the last 3 years, presents to the emergency department with a cough, breathing difficulty, and increased expectoration for a day. There is no history of fever. His regular medications include inhaled salmeterol and inhaled fluticasone propionate. He was a chronic smoker but quit smoking 2 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), the pulse rate is 88/min, the blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg, and the respirations are 30/min. On physical examination, the use of the accessory muscles of respiration is evident and the arterial saturation of oxygen is 87%. Auscultation of the chest reveals the presence of bilateral rhonchi with diminished breath sounds in both lungs. Which of the following medications, if administered for the next 2 weeks, is most likely to reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months?A)Oral prednisone
B)Supplemental oxygen
C)Montelukast
D)Nebulized N-acetylcysteine
output0: Oral prednisone is the most likely medication to reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months. This is because prednisone is a corticosteroid that can help to reduce inflammation in the lungs and improve lung function. Additionally, prednisone has been shown to reduce the risk of exacerbations in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
output1: Supplemental oxygen is the most likely medication to reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months in this patient with chronic obstructive lung disease. This is because supplemental oxygen can help to increase the patient's arterial oxygen saturation, which can improve their respiratory function and reduce the risk of exacerbations.
output2: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist that is commonly used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations. Studies have shown that montelukast can reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months when used in conjunction with inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. The other options are not effective in reducing the risk of subsequent exacerbations.
output3: Nebulized N-acetylcysteine is the most likely medication to reduce the risk of subsequent exacerbations over the next 6 months in this patient with chronic obstructive lung disease. This medication works by reducing inflammation in the airways and improving lung function. It is also well-tolerated and has a relatively short duration of action.

question: female patient came with right side hearing loss, better heard in a noisy environment,Audiogram shown with about 30-40 dB gap between AC-BC of right & left ear. Rinne's test negative, Weber's test centralised. Which of the following condition shown?
prompt:
female patient came with right side hearing loss, better heard in a noisy environment,Audiogram shown with about 30-40 dB gap between AC-BC of right & left ear. Rinne's test negative, Weber's test centralised. Which of the following condition shown?A)Meniere's disease
B)stapedial otosclerosis
C)Presbycusis
D)Vestibular schwannoma
output0: The patient's symptoms of better hearing in noisy environments and the negative Rinne's test suggest Meniere's disease. Additionally, the 30-40 dB gap between the AC-BC of the right and left ear is consistent with the typical hearing loss pattern seen in Meniere's disease.
output1: The patient's symptoms of better hearing in a noisy environment and the negative Rinne's test suggest that the hearing loss is conductive in nature. The centralized Weber's test, however, indicates that the hearing loss is not due to a problem in the outer ear or ear canal. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is stapedial otosclerosis, a condition in which there is fixation of the stapes bone in the middle ear, leading to conductive hearing loss.
output2: The patient's hearing loss, as shown by the audiogram, is consistent with presbycusis, which is a type of hearing loss that occurs as a result of aging. The fact that the patient is better able to hear in noisy environments and the negative results of the Rinne's and Weber's tests also support this diagnosis.
output3: The patient's symptoms of hearing loss in one ear, better hearing in noisy environments, and a negative Rinne's test suggest that the patient may have a vestibular schwannoma, also known as a acoustic neuroma. This is a benign tumor that grows on the vestibular nerve and can cause hearing loss and tinnitus. The centralized Weber's test also supports this diagnosis.

question: According to the DSM (IV-TR and 5) Which of the following is required to diagnose Tourette Disorder ?:
correct_answer: That the tics persist for more than a year since the appearance of the first tic.
options: A)A beginning of the symptoms before the 12 years.
B)That motor tics and vocal tics have been present at some time of the disease concurrently.
C)That the tics persist for more than a year since the appearance of the first tic.
D)That at least 3 vocal tics have been present.
prompt:
According to the DSM (IV-TR and 5) Which of the following is required to diagnose Tourette Disorder ?:A)A beginning of the symptoms before the 12 years.
B)That motor tics and vocal tics have been present at some time of the disease concurrently.
C)That the tics persist for more than a year since the appearance of the first tic.
D)That at least 3 vocal tics have been present.
output0: To diagnose Tourette Disorder, the symptoms must have begun before the age of 12. This is a diagnostic criterion for the disorder, as stated in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR and DSM-5).
output1: To diagnose Tourette Disorder, it is required that the individual has had both motor and vocal tics at some point in the course of the disorder. This is specified in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition, Text Revision (DSM-IV-TR) and the 5th Edition (DSM-5).
output2: To diagnose Tourette Disorder, the symptoms must persist for at least one year since the appearance of the first tic. This is a requirement outlined in the DSM-IV-TR and DSM-5. The other options are not correct requirements for diagnosis.
output3: According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV-TR and 5), at least three vocal tics must be present to diagnose Tourette Disorder. This is because vocal tics are a key symptom of the disorder.
